feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll feature that automatically computes and deducts daily pay for employees taking unpaid leave. It calculates the appropriate salary reduction by dividing the employee's total salary (basic plus allowance) by the actual number of working or calendar days in the month. The system accounts for public holidays by subtracting them from the working day count before calculating the daily rate. Upon approval of an unpaid leave request, the calculator automatically generates a corresponding pay deduction that is reflected on the payroll table. This ensures accurate and consistent salary adjustments based on the organization's leave policy framework.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. It defines the daily pay formula as Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) divided by the number of actual working days in the month. The article clarifies that leave policies can be based on calendar days (30 days) or working days (22 days), and that public holidays must be deducted from the working days count. Upon approval of an unpaid leave request, an automatic pay deduction is created and reflected on the payroll table.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introductory article explaining the Daily Wage Calculator feature, its purpose, and the three calculation base options (calendar days, working days, custom days). Covers salary component selection, access path (Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation), and the three main payroll areas impacted: salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction. Includes definitions of each calculation base and notes compliance with UAE and KSA labor law requirements.

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article documents how Super admins can update salary proration settings in the Daily Wage Calculator (DWC) by selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). It explains that proration affects first salary and end-of-service settlements, describes the navigation path (Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation), and details the requirement to reject existing prorated transactions when the payroll month is open before saving new proration settings. Changes immediately impact all active unpaid payroll amounts.

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and a salary deduction needs to be calculated and applied
steps: Receive and approve the unpaid leave request
Determine the organization's leave policy (calendar days or working days)
Identify the total number of days in the policy (e.g., 30 calendar days or 22 working days)
Identify all public holidays falling in the month
Deduct public holidays from the total working days to calculate actual working days
Calculate daily pay using the formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Actual Working Days
Automatically generate and apply the pay deduction to the payroll table

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up or modifying how daily wages are calculated for salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions.
steps: Select calculation base: calendar days, working days, or custom days
Choose salary components to include in calculation (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only)
Save configuration to apply to payroll calculations

procedures.when_to_use: When Super admin needs to change how employee salaries are prorated based on days worked, or when adjusting calculation methodology for payroll accuracy
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select the required calculation basis: custom days, calendar days, or working days
If payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions, reject those transactions before saving new proration settings
Confirm the new proration settings are applied

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay is calculated by dividing total salary (basic plus allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month ; The leave policy determines whether calculations are based on calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 days) ; Public holidays falling in the month must be deducted from the working days count before calculating daily pay ; Pay deductions are automatically created upon approval of an unpaid leave request and are reflected on the payroll table

Calendar days calculation uses the actual number of days in each month (e.g., 31 days in January, 28 days in February), resulting in variable daily wage rates month-to-month. ; Working days calculation excludes weekends and public holidays as defined in the company's public holiday calendar, resulting in fewer billable days than calendar days. ; Custom days calculation allows flexibility to set a fixed number of days per month according to company policies; most UAE and KSA companies use 30 custom days to comply with local labor law requirements. ; The selected calculation base and salary components directly impact the final daily wage rates used for salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction calculations.

The daily wage calculator is a payroll feature that automatically computes and deducts daily pay for employees taking unpaid leave. The system accounts for public holidays by subtracting them from the working day count before calculating the daily rate. Upon approval of an unpaid leave request, the calculator automatically generates a corresponding pay deduction that is reflected on the payroll table.
